z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam emission spectroscopy diagnostic on the DIII-D tokamak
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Emission spectroscopy|Particle beams|Plasma density|Plasma turbulence|Two dimensional|Spurious signal noise|Fiber optics|Optical resolving power|Optical instrument lenses|Frequency response|Light emitting diodes|Field effect transistors
z:row.Publisher: American Institute of Physics Inc., Woodbury, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new beam emission spectroscopy (BES) system was developed to measure spatially localized, long-wavelength density fluctuations in the core and edge regions of tokamak plasmas. To deploy the BES diagnostic on DIII-D, numerous advances and technological innovations were required. The advances considered provided a new BES system on DIII-D whose capabilities are significantly advance beyond those of previous BES systems on other experiments. This article describes the major subsystems of this improved BES apparatus. It also demonstrates the ability to reconfigure the viewing optics to allow two-dimension measurements of the density fluctuations.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Beam emission spectroscopy; Turbulent density; Electronic noise

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurement of local ion diffusion coefficients in the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor
z:row.Keyword: plasma density|plasma diagnostics|plasma temperature|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The perturbations in ion temperature, density and parallel velocity resulting from sawtooth disruptions in TFTR are measured with a novel diagnostic. The local ion thermal diffusivity, particle diffusivity and parallel momentum diffusivity are determined in a high power discharge at r/a=0.64 by fitting the observed pulses to a simple model of the radial diffusive propagation of heat, particles and momentum caused by the crash. The incremental ion thermal diffusivity, χiinc, is found to be similar in amplitude to the ion and electron thermal diffusivities obtained from a steady state 1-D power balance analysis, and the particle and parallel momentum diffusivities are found to be an order of magnitude smaller than χiinc
z:row.User2: Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor; ion temperature; ion density; parallel velocity; sawtooth; local ion thermal diffusivity; particle diffusivity; TFTR; electron thermal diffusivities; ion thermal diffusivity; parallel momentum diffusivity

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experiences with remote collaborations in fusion research
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1997 17th IEEE/NPSS Symposium Fusion Engineering. Part 2 (of 2), Oct 6-10 1997
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Engineering research|Fusion reactions|Distributed computer systems|Wide area networks|Data reduction
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: San Diego, CA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Princeton Plasma Physics Lab, NJ, USA
z:row.Abstract: The magnetic fusion research community has considerable experience in placing remote collaboration tools in the hands of real users. The ability to remotely view operations and to control selected instrumentation and analysis tasks has been demonstrated. University of Wisconsin scientists making turbulence measurements on TFTR were provided with a remote control room from which they could operate their diagnostic, while keeping in close contact with their colleagues in Princeton. LLNL has assembled a remote control room in Livermore in support of a large, long term collaboration on the DIII-D tokamak in San Diego. From the same control room, a joint team of MIT and LLNL scientists has conducted full functional operation of the Alcator C-Mod tokamak located 3,000 miles away in Cambridge Massachusetts. These early efforts have been highly successful, but are only the first steps needed to demonstrate the technical feasibility of a complete 'facilities on line' environment. These efforts have provided a 'proof of principle' for the collaboratory concept and they have also pointed out shortcomings in current generation tools and approaches. Current experiences and future directions will be discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Remote collaboration; Energy science network; Fusion research

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fusion reactivity characterization of a spherically convergent ion focus
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The deuterium-deuterium (D-D) fusion reaction rate in a spherically convergent ion focus is observed to significantly exceed the rate predicted by a collisionless flow model. However, a careful consideration of ion-neutral collisions and the trapped neutral density in the cathode account for the extra reactivity without invoking anomalous ion trapping in the converged core region. This conclusion is supported by proton collimation measurements, which indicate that the bulk of the observed reactivity originates outside the core region. In addition, a classical flow model, where charge exchange collisional effects on the ion and fast neutral distributions are included, provides fusion rate estimates that are quantitatively consistent with the observed D-D fusion neutron production rat.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Ion trapping; Convergent ion focus; Proton collimation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wisconsin Pegasus solenoid
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1997 5th International Symposium on Research in High Magnetic Fields, RHMF'97, Aug 4-6 1997
z:row.Keyword: Magnets|Magnetic fields|Solenoids|Tokamak devices|Plasma density|Glass|Carbon fibers|Steel|Current density
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Sydney, Aust
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Natl High Magnetic Field Lab, Tallahassee, FL, USA
z:row.Abstract: A 1.6 m long×0.1 m diameter coil has just been constructed by the NHMFL for the University of Wisconsin Pegasus Tokamak. It will form the central solenoid for the high plasma energy density fusion machine. The magnet consists of two layers of Glidcop conductor, reinforced with S2 glass, carbon fiber and steel. Normal operating parameters will be 14 T in a 58 mm bore with a number of pulses to 20 T+. Current densities will approach 1 kA/mm2 and the stored energy will >2 MJ. The philosophy behind the design will be presented and details of the construction and testing will be shown.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of ion temperature fluctuations in the tokamak fusion test reactor
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Plasma confinement|Temperature measurement|Ions|Thermal gradients|Density of gases|Experimental reactors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: First of a king measurements of high-frequency ion temperature microturbulence in fusion-grade plasmas have been made in TFTR. The ion temperature fluctuations and carbon density fluctuations were found to have spectra similar to those of the ion density fluctuations across the plasma radius. The ratio of the relative fluctuation levels, (T(over-tilde)/T)/(n(over-tilde)/n), is 2±0.5 from r/a = 0.59 to r/a = 0.99. The fact that this ratio is greater than unity is consistent with the general expectations of ion temperature gradient driven turbulence theory and suggests that ion drift modes dominate trapped electron modes in the turbulent spectrum. The temperature fluctuation spectra were found to exhibit a narrow transition region between distinctive edge and core turbulent modes, as has been seen with ion density fluctuations. The ratio of the relative fluctuation levels is greater than unity across this transition, which suggests that, despite the different modes present, the underlying instability is driven by the ion temperature gradient.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Tokamak fusion test reactors (TFTR); Ion temperature fluctuations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Convergence, electrostatic potential, and density measurements in a spherically convergent ion focus
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Unique measurements of the basic plasma-flow characteristics in a low pressure (⩽53 mPa H2) spherically convergent ion focus are obtained using high-voltage (⩽5 kV) emissive and double probes. The radial plasma potential distribution agrees with a collisionless, recirculating, space-charge-limited current model. Flow convergence increases with voltage and neutral pressure and decreases with cathode grid wire spacing and current. Core radii within 4-5 times the ideal geometric limit are measured, and the observed core sizes are consistent with predictions from a multipass orbit model which includes asymmetries in the accelerating potential well. A virtual anode is observed in the converged core region, and no evidence for multiple potential well structures in the core is found. Measurements of the core ion density (nic~1015 m-3) are consistent with simple flow convergence models

z:row.Abstract: Fusion produced non-thermal alpha particle radial profile measurements are obtained with the α-CHERS diagnostic in deuterium-tritium (DT) supershot plasmas on the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR). Alpha particles in the energy range 0.15 α 17 m-3. The profiles obtained in two sets of discharges vary slightly, and are best described by a slowing down alpha distribution subject to neoclassical diffusion plus a small anomalous cross-field diffusion. The data are consistent with an effective anomalous diffusion coefficient in the range 0.00 . The profiles obtained in two sets of discharges vary slightly, and are best described by a slowing down alpha distribution subject to neoclassical diffusion plus a small anomalous cross-field diffusion. z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of sawtooth redistribution of non-thermal, confined alpha particles in TFTR DT discharges
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Princeton Univ, NJ, USA
z:row.Abstract: Radial profiles of the density of confined alpha particles with energies in the 0.15 to 0.6 MeV range are spectroscopically observed before and after a sawtooth crash in a TFTR deuterium-tritium plasma. A large drop in the core alpha density is seen, indicating expulsion of alphas from the core to the plasma periphery. The measured changes in the alpha density profiles are consistent with predictions based on the Kolesnichenko sawtooth model in this case.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Low aspect ratio tokamak startup and heating using waves in the ion cyclotron range of frequencies
z:row.TitleSecondary: Radio Frequency Power in Plasmas. 12th Topical Conference, 1-3 April 1997
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Savannah, GA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Radio frequency auxiliary heating for low aspect ratio tokamaks can facilitate startup and access to high energy density plasmas, reduce the demand on ohmic core volt-seconds, and provide off axis electron heating for a high βe plasma. Calculations for several waves both below and at high harmonics of the ion cyclotron frequency predict significant RF heating even at the lower electron temperatures and densities typical of startup plasmas. Real time adjustments of the antenna array phasing can track plasma startup evolution

z:row.TitlePrimary: Alfven ion-ion hybrid wave heating in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|plasma Alfven waves|plasma density|plasma heating|plasma instability|plasma toroidal confinement|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: In the Phaedrus-T tokamak [R.A. Breun et al., Fusion Technol. 19, 1327 (1991)], Alfven waves are indirectly driven by a fast wave antenna array. Small fractions of minority ions are shown to have a large effect on the Alfven spectrum, as measured at the edge. An ion-ion hybrid Alfven mode has been identified by measuring dispersion properties. Landau damping is predicted to be large and spatially localized. These Alfvenic waves are experimentally shown to generate correlated electron heating and changes in density near the core of the tokamak plasma. Fast wave antenna fields can mode convert at a hybrid Alfven resonance and provide a promising route to spatially localized tokamak heating and current drive, even for low effective ionic charge Zeff≈1.3-2
z:row.User2: Alfven ion-ion hybrid wave heating; Phaedrus-T tokamak; indirectly driven Alfven waves; fast wave antenna array; minority ions; Alfven spectrum; ion-ion hybrid Alfven mode; dispersion properties measurement; spatially localised Landau damping; correlated electron heating; plasma density changes; tokamak plasma; fast wave antenna fields; mode conversion; hybrid Alfven resonance; spatially localized tokamak heating; spatially localized current drive; effective ionic charge

z:row.TitlePrimary: Technique for the experimental estimation of nonlinear energy transfer in fully developed turbulence
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new procedure for calculating the nonlinear energy transfer and linear growth/damping rate of fully developed turbulence is derived. It avoids the unphysically large damping rates typically obtained using the predecessor method of Ritz [Ch.P. Ritz, E.J. Powers, and R.D. Bengtson, Phys. Fluids B 1, 153 (1989)]. It enforces stationarity of the turbulence to reduce the effects of noise and fluctuations not described by the basic governing equation, and includes the fourth-order moment to avoid the closure approximation. The new procedure has been implemented and tested on simulated, fully developed two-dimensional (2-D) turbulence data from a 2-D trapped-particle fluid code, and has been shown to give excellent reconstructions of the input growth rate and nonlinear coupling coefficients with good noise rejection. However, in the experimentally important case where only a one-dimensional (1-D) averaged representation of the underlying 2-D turbulence is available, this technique does not, in general, give acceptable results. A new 1-D algorithm has thus been developed for analysis of 1-D measurements of intrinsically 2-D turbulence. This new 1-D algorithm includes the nonresonant wave numbers in calculating the bispectra, and generally gives useful results when the width of the radial wave number spectrum is comparable to or less than that of the poloidal spectrum
z:row.User2: nonlinear energy transfer; fully developed turbulence; linear growth/damping rate; damping rates; noise; fluctuations; governing equation; fourth-order moment; closure approximation; simulated fully developed two-dimensional turbulence data; two-dimensional trapped-particle fluid code; input growth rate; nonlinear coupling coefficients; nonresonant wave numbers; bispectra; radial wave number spectrum; poloidal spectrum

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fast flow phenomena in a toroidal plasma
z:row.TitleSecondary: 36th Annual Meeting of the Division of Plasma Physics of the American Physical Society, 7-11 Nov. 1994
z:row.Keyword: plasma diagnostics|plasma flow|reversed field pinch|sawtooth instability|tearing instability
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Minneapolis, MN, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The bulk fluid velocity is measured spectroscopically with 10 μs time resolution in the Madison Symmetric Torus (MST) reversed-field pinch (RFP) [Fusion Technol. 19, 131 (1991)], a diagnostic capability used to study the fast flow dynamics associated with locked modes and the RFP dynamo. The phase velocity of the tearing modes and the fluid velocity accelerate between sawtooth events, reaching a maximum speed of about 20 km/s in a few ms. Both slow down at the sawtooth crash in ≈100 μs. This deceleration time scale is as calculated for the tearing modes from the action of electromagnetic torque on the magnetic islands, but is much faster than expected from the viscous torque on the bulk fluid. In the RFP, correlated fluctuations in the tearing modes and fluid velocity probably also generate current via the “RFP dynamo,” ⟨u˜×B˜⟩, where u is the bulk fluid velocity. Initial data indicate a possible increase in ⟨u˜φB˜r⟩ during sawtooth events, coincident with toroidal flux generation
z:row.User2: toroidal plasma; fast flow phenomena; bulk fluid velocity; time resolution; Madison symmetric torus reversed-field pinch; diagnostic capability; locked modes; RFP dynamics; phase velocity; tearing modes; fluid velocity; sawtooth events; sawtooth crash; deceleration time scale; electromagnetic torque; magnetic islands; viscous torque; toroidal flux generation; 10 mus; 20 km/s

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma flow and magnetic mode rotation in the MST reversed-field pinch
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: Doppler effect|Doppler shift|plasma diagnostics|plasma flow|plasma fluctuations|plasma impurities|reversed field pinch|sawtooth instability|tearing instability
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. We measure the bulk fluid velocity with 100 kHz resolution in the MST reversed-field pinch (RFP). This diagnostic capability provides the ability to study the fast flow dynamics associated with locked modes. A fast duo-spectrometer simultaneously measures the red and blue Doppler shifts of spectral line radiation emitted by impurity ions in the hydrogen plasma. The phase velocity of the magnetic fluctuations of the tearing modes is measured with a toroidal array of magnetic pickup coils. Both velocities track each other very closely during the spinup phase between sawtooth events, typically reaching a maximum speed of about 20 km/s. Both slow down at the sawtooth crash within a few tens of microseconds. Locked modes in MST occur coincident with the large impulsive vertical field associated with a sawtooth event; they can also be controllably induced by a negatively biased electrode inserted into the plasma. After the onset of a locked mode the phase velocity of the magnetic fluctuations is zero, while the bulk fluid continues to flow at a velocity of few km/s
z:row.User2: plasma flow; magnetic mode rotation; MST reversed-field pinch; bulk fluid velocity; diagnostic capability; fast flow dynamics; locked modes; fast duo-spectrometer; red Doppler shifts; blue Doppler shifts; spectral line radiation; impurity ions; H plasma; magnetic fluctuations; tearing modes; toroidal array of magnetic pickup coils; sawtooth events; large impulsive vertical field; negatively biased electrode; 20 km/s

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of 15th International Symposium on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 26 Sept.-1 Oct. 1994

z:row.Keyword: antennas in plasma|fusion reactor design|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor limiters|plasma Alfven waves|plasma heating|plasma instability|plasma simulation|plasma toroidal confinement
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seville, Spain
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental results from the Phaedrus-T tokamak AWCD programme include the first successful demonstration of Alfven wave current drive (with ωi) in a tokamak. 46 kA of Alfven wave current drive (AWCD)-compared to a total current of 64 kA-has been driven. Alfven wave heating (AWH) of electrons is also demonstrated during H-mode operation (achieved with a biased electrode). Alfven wave excitation is achieved with conventional loop antennas and with a new type of antenna (stacked stripline) which allows very low voltage operation. Antennas have no Faraday screens but employ insulating limiters. Theoretical studies suggest that wave excitation in Phaedrus-T depends on the presence of a minority species. The time dependence of the loop voltage has successfully been modelled. Alfven wave heating and current drive regimes and low frequency fast wave current drive regimes in tokamaks, Phaedrus-T, TPX and ITER have been analysed via the global full wave code, ALFA
z:row.User2: Alfven wave heating; Alfven wave current drive; Phaedrus-T tokamak; H-mode operation; biased electrode; loop antennas; stacked stripline; very low voltage operation; insulating limiters; wave excitation; minority species; low frequency fast wave current drive; TPX; ITER; global full wave code; ALFA code; fusion reactor; 64 kA; 46 kA

z:row.Abstract: A high-resolution spectrometer has been developed and used on the MST reversed-field pinch (RFP) to measure passively impurity ion temperatures and flow velocities with 10 μs temporal resolution. Such measurements of MHD-scale fluctuations are particularly relevant in the RFP because the flow velocity fluctuation-induced transport of current (the “MHD dynamo”) may produce the magnetic field reversal characteristic of an RFP. This instrument will also be used to measure rapid changes in the equilibrium flow velocity, such as occur during locking and H-mode transition. The precision of measurements made to date is u and B from the fluctuations due to rigid shifts of the plasma column

z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. A fast and inexpensive spectrometer system has been developed to record EUV impurity spectra in the Madison Symmetric Torus (MST) Reversed-Field Pinch (RFP). To simplify the vacuum system, light is passed out of the spectrometer's vacuum to the detector using a sodium-salicylate-coated fiber-optic coupler. This coupler is positioned such that the focal field is nearly flat over its aperture, thus minimizing defocusing at the edges of the detection plane. The system's detector is a microchannel-plate-intensified, linear, self-scanning photodiode array. The 1024-pixel array covers a bandwidth of over 80 nm and is read out once every ms. The readout, which is four times faster than the manufacturer's maximum rating, is fully synchronized to the experiment using a locally designed control circuit

z:row.Abstract: The bulk of the low-amplitude turbulent density fluctuations are found in the range (k1ρi)≈0.1-0.3 for supershot and L-mode confinement regimes in TFTR. The wavenumber spectrum in the radial direction peaks at kr=0, while the poloidal spectrum peaks near k&thetas;ρi≈0.1-0.3, in general agreement with expectations from nonlinear ion drift wave turbulence models. A nonlinear wave-wave coupling analysis indicates a positive linear growth rate at very low k&thetas;ρii observed at smaller radii in the plasma

z:row.Abstract: A two-dimensional analog to the beam emission spectroscopy (BES) diagnostic has been designed to acquire vorticity and plasma flow-field information by resolving the spatial and temporal intermittency of plasma turbulent structures. The beam emission imaging diagnostic measures collisionally induced neutral beam fluorescence to infer local plasma density variations. It consists of a high-throughput, interline-transfer CCD camera viewing, with narrow spectral bandwidth, a 10 cm high diagnostic neutral beam as it traverses the plasma. The camera is coupled to a gated image intensifier that provides for two images with exposure times up to a few ms to be separated by as little as 10 μs. Sensitivity to density fluctuations of /n>1.0% is expected using the Phaedrus-T beam operating at 20-25 keV in He0 or D0

z:row.TitleSecondary: Tenth Topical Conference on High-Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 8-12 May 1994

z:row.Abstract: The α-CHERS diagnostic is a high throughput charge exchange recombination spectroscopy diagnostic designed to measure the density profile and time evolution of 0-500 keV alpha particles during D-T operation of the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR). Following successful tests with a prototype α-CHERS system, an improved, multichannel system has been installed for D-T operation. Three spatial channels may be observed simultaneously, and the spectral resolution of 0.5 nm permits increased alpha energy resolution and improved impurity line identification. More efficient coupling optics between the spectrometer and charge coupled device (CCD) detectors have increased the light throughput, and radiation shielding has been installed around the detectors and spectrometers to eliminate the neutron/gamma-ray noise observed in high power D-D plasmas

z:row.TitlePrimary: Confined alpha distribution measurements in a deuterium-tritium tokamak plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Fusion-produced alpha particles with energy ⩽0.7 MeV have been spectroscopically observed in the core of a deuterium-tritium plasma in the TFTR tokamak at alpha densities of 3×1016 m-3. During a sawtooth-free discharge, the measured energy spectra at r/a=0.3 are in good agreement with those predicted on the basis of collisional transport. Time-resolved measurements during the alpha thermalization after alpha source turn-off show decay of the distribution function to lower energies consistent with the classical slowing-down time of 0.5 s

z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995

z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Convergent ion focus devices have been considered as sources of fusion reactivity since early studies in the late 1960's. In general, these devices rely on the confinement and acceleration of plasma ions in a spherically or cylindrically symmetric electrostatic potential well. Ions at the edge fall into the well and converge to the central core region. This leads to a strongly increasing central density and central ion energies comparable to the depth of the potential well, resulting in considerable fusion reactivity with modest device parameters. Several schemes have been proposed for creating the potential well, with simple transparent spherical grids being the usual experimental realization. Potential applications of these fusion devices range from small low-intensity fusion-product particle sources for nuclear assaying to more intense sources for isotope generation and waste processing. Even more optimistic projections have led to discussions of fusion power generation through electrostatic confinement. Recent experiments and modelling efforts are developing a deeper understanding of the operation of these devices. Near-term future experiments are concentrating on development of nonperturbing diagnostics of the energetic ion core, achieving high core density operation, and testing predictions of flow instabilities
z:row.User2: spherically convergent ion focus; convergent ion focus devices; fusion reactivity; plasma confinement; plasma acceleration; plasma ions; cylindrically symmetric electrostatic potential well; spherically symmetric electrostatic potential well; central core region; central density; central ion energies; transparent spherical grids; fusion devices; low-intensity fusion-product particle sources; nuclear assaying; isotope generation; waste processing; fusion power generation; electrostatic confinement; nonperturbing diagnostics; energetic ion core; high core density operation; flow instabilities

z:row.Abstract: A novel undergraduate engineering physics program is under consideration as an addition to our present nuclear engineering program. The two undergraduate programs are designed to have a common first two years and the content of the courses are streamlined so that courses do double duty for both curricula as much as possible. The engineering physics curriculum emphasizes student involvement in team research and development projects throughout the program and allows students to tailor the program to individual interests by appropriate choice of engineering physics electives.

z:row.Abstract: The implementation of beam emission spectroscopy (BES) on the tokamak TEXT-U was achieved by the construction of a compact, robustly portable, eight-channel filter spectrometer. The wave number spectra of the long wavelength density spectra were experimentally observed to be asymmetric with the poloidal spectra peaked at higher k: [Left angle bracket]kr[Right Angle Bracket] [Right Angle Bracket] [Right Angle Bracket] θ[Right Angle Bracket]. This suggested that the higher resolution was needed in the poloidal direction to resolve the fluctuations. The system can be configured with bundles which give symmetric resolution of 6 mm by 6 mm with asymmetric fiber bundles which have poloidal and radial resolutions of 6 and 17 mm, respectively. The spectrum exhibited by the correlation method was characteristic of both TEXT-U and Phaedrus-T. Detailed study showed that the fluctuations in the core region of these machines were very similar to those observed in the edge region of tokamak fusion test reactor.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.Abstract: A high-throughput, four-spectral-channel, high-frequency charge exchange recombination spectroscopy diagnostic was installed on Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor, which will measure localized temperature and parallel velocity fluctuations from investigation of the n=8-7 emission of C+5. Comparison with beam emission spectroscopy revealed that sensitivity to temperature fluctuations of <=1% was predicted. The charge exchange line was determined and measured by phase I, and early temperature and change-in-velocity estimates from this diagnostic corresponded well with the results from charge exchange recombination spectroscopy.

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A high-resolution spectrometer has been developed and used to measure simultaneously impurity ion temperatures and flow velocities in high temperature plasmas with 10 μs temporal resolution (limited by digitization rate). This device is actually a duo-spectrometer: measurements from two different chordal views of the plasma can be made simultaneously via two separate quartz input fiber optic bundles coupled to the entrance slits which are tilted to compensate for line curvature. The dispersed spectra on the exit plane of the duo-spectrometer are coupled via quartz fiber optics to two arrays of 16 photomultiplier tubes each. Measurements made by recording the Doppler broadened and shifted 227.091 nm emission from the Cv impurity ions in the Madison Symmetric Torus (MST) reversed-field pinch (RFP) plasma have achieved precisions of <6 eV for temperatures of 150 eV and <0.7 km/s for flow velocities of 6 km/s. Representative results from the MST RFP indicate that the toroidal flow velocity drops and ion temperature increase during sawtooth events in MST

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of a localized transition from edge to core density turbulence in the TFTR tokamak
z:row.Keyword: discharges (electric)|fluctuations|plasma density|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma turbulence|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A localized transition zone is observed between turbulent, long-wavelength density fluctuations (k⊥-1) in the core and edge of beam-heated discharges in TFTR. The core turbulence is unimodal while the edge has two counterpropagating modes, both of which are spectrally distinct from the core fluctuations. The fluctuation amplitude in the core scales with the global energy confinement time while in the edge it does not. These observations suggest that distinct modes are responsible for turbulence in the two regions and that only the core mode is directly related to global confinement

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam emission spectroscopy diagnosis of turbulence in high temperature tokamak plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: Conference Record - Abstracts 1993 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Beam Emission Spectroscopy (BES) is a relatively new diagnostic technique which provides localized measurements of density turbulence in high temperature magnetically-confined plasmas. Characterization of this turbulence is an important experimental requirement towards the goal of understanding the microturbulence which is suspected as the cause of the anomalously high cross-field transport in tokamaks. BES detects local plasma fluctuations by observing intensity fluctuations in collisionally induced neutral beam fluorescence from a diagnostic beam injected into the hot plasma. Determination of the local fluctuation temporal and spatial spectra involves several steps: a) conversion of the intensity fluctuation amplitude to a local density fluctuation amplitude via a multistep atomic excitation model; b) elimination of the effects of incoherent photon counting statistical noise from the measured correlation function; c) elimination of common mode interference arising from beam density fluctuations induced by large plasma fluctuation amplitudes in the plasma edge region; and d) accurate modeling of the spatial response transfer function for normalization of the wavenumber spectrum.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Beam emission spectroscopy diagnosis; High temperature Tokamak plasmas; Plasma edge region; High temperature magnetically-confined plasmas; Density turbulence measurement; Multistep atomic excitation model

z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1992. Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 30 Sept.-7 Oct. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1992. Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Wuerzburg, Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: New information on magnetic fluctuations and transport in toroidal devices has been obtained in the MST reversed field pinch through measurement of nonlinear coupling of three waves in k-space, and measurement of current density fluctuations. Measurements of nonlinear coupling of magnetic fluctuations reveal that (1) two poloidal mode number m=1 modes couple strongly to an m=2 mode; (2) toroidal mode coupling is broad, extending up to n≈20; (3) these features agree with predictions for tearing fluctuations from a nonlinear MHD code; (4) during a sawtooth crash the number of modes involved in nonlinear interactions increases dramatically and the k-spectrum broadens simultaneously. Measurements of current density fluctuations over the outer 20% of the minor radius reveal that (1) low frequency fluctuations are consistent with tearing modes; (2) high frequency fluctuations are localized turbulence which maintains resonance with the equilibrium field as q changes with radius; (3) particle transport from magnetic fluctuations is ambipolar (i.e. ⟨δj∥δBr⟩≈0)
z:row.User2: ambipolar particle transport; nonlinear coupling; transport; magnetic fluctuations; toroidal devices; MST reversed field pinch; k-space; current density fluctuations; poloidal mode number; m=1 modes; m=2 mode; toroidal mode coupling; tearing fluctuations; nonlinear MHD code; sawtooth crash; equilibrium field

z:row.TitlePrimary: Anomalous ion heating and superthermal electrons in the MST reversed-field pinch
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1992. Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 30 Sept.-7 Oct. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1992. Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Wuerzburg, Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Anomalous ion heating and superthermal electron populations have been studied in the MST reversed-field pinch. The ion heating is much stronger than that given by classical electron-ion friction, and is particularly strong during dynamo bursts. The heating displays a market density dependence: in a 350 kA discharge with a maximum n¯=0.9×1013 cm-3, Ti rises sharply as n¯ drops below 0.4×1013 cm-3 late in the discharge. Superthermal electrons are produced in the core, with temperatures of Teh=350-700 eV, while the bulk core temperature is Te0=130-230 eV. The fraction of superthermal electrons decreases with increasing density, from 40% at n¯=0.5×1013 cm-3 to 8% at n¯=1.9×1013 cm-3 at I=350 kA. However, data with similar plasma parameters but higher oxygen impurity content had a lower Teh and a higher hot fraction. The edge superthermal electron distribution is well fit by a drifted bi-Maxwellian distribution with T∥~Te0 and relative drift speed υd/υth=0.4. With the assumption that the parallel heat flux measured with a pyroelectric probe is carried by superthermal electrons, the measured electron current is consistent with T⊥~Tea~Te0/3 and accounts for over half of the total edge parallel current measured with magnetic probes
z:row.User2: anomalous ion heating; superthermal electrons; MST reversed-field pinch; electron populations; classical electron-ion friction; dynamo bursts; density dependence; impurity content; hot fraction; drifted bi-Maxwellian distribution; parallel heat flux; pyroelectric probe; edge parallel current; magnetic probes; 350 kA; 350 to 700 eV; O

z:row.Abstract: Heating in the Alfven resonant regime has been demonstrated in the Phaedrus-T tokamak [Fusion Technol. 19, 1327 (1991)]. Electron heating during injection of radio-frequency (RF) power is indicated by a 30%-40% drop in loop voltage and modifications in sawtooth activity. Heating was observed at a frequency ωrf≈0.7 Ωi on axis, using a two-strap fast wave antenna operated at 76 and 9.2 MHz with 180° phasing (N∥~100). Numerical modeling with the fast wave code FASTWA [Plasma Phys. Controlled Fusion 33, 417 (1991)] indicates that for Phaedrus-T parameters the kinetic Alfven wave is excited via mode conversion from a surface fast wave at the Alfven resonance and is subsequently damped on electrons

z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given. Beam emission spectroscopy (BES) is a diagnostic technique which provides localized measurements of density turbulence in high-temperature magnetically confined plasmas. BES detects local plasma fluctuations by observing intensity fluctuations in collisionally induced neutral beam fluorescence from a diagnostic beam injected into the hot plasma. With this approach it is possible to access the wavelength region of peak fluctuation amplitude in the plasma, and new features of the turbulence spectrum have emerged. For example, a strong anisotropy is observed in the wavenumber spectra perpendicular to the local field, where the radial spectrum peaks at k4 = 0 cm-1, while the poloidal spectrum peaks at k&thetas; ≈ 1 cm-1. Estimates of turbulence-driven fluxes indicate that the observed fluctuations are sufficient to driven the observed anomalous cross-field transport in tokamak plasmas with strong auxiliary heating

z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA

z:row.Abstract: Plasma density turbulence has been measured with the beam emission spectroscopy (BES) diagnostic system, using a low-power neutral beam with He0 and H0 as beam species. In general, He0 (588 nm) provided the best signal-to-noise ratio due to its lower edge plasma background interference. Simultaneous measurements of edge density fluctuations have been made with BES and Langmuir probes; the spectra are seen to be essentially identical, and the fluctuation amplitudes from both diagnostics are in close agreement. A poloidal coherence length of about 2-4 cm was observed. Radial propagation of modes was not seen, but a lab-frame poloidal phase velocity at r/a=0.77 of about 7×105 cm/s in the electron diamagnetic direction was observed, corresponding to m=8-75 kHz
z:row.User2: optical fluctuation; plasma density; turbulence; diagnostic beam; Phaedrus-T; density; signal-to-noise ratio; plasma; edge density fluctuations; Langmuir probes; poloidal coherence length; 588 nm; He; H

z:row.TitlePrimary: Effects of edge plasma turbulence on radial correlation length measurements with BES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The recently developed technique of beam emission spectroscopy (BES) provides a tool to study long-wavelength density turbulence (coherence length ≫ ion gyroradius) in hot tokamak plasmas. To provide an accurate conversion of the measured light intensity fluctuations to a local /n density fluctuation and to assess the influence of density fluctuations in the neutral beam induced by large edge turbulence, a multistate neutral beam excitation/transport code for realistic experimental geometries has been written. Results from this code show that the attenuation of the beam density induced by edge turbulence can give rise to significant levels of common-mode fluctuation power in signals from the plasma core and that the derivation of quantitative values of /n from experimental measurements depends weakly on the radial extent of the density fluctuations
z:row.User2: edge plasma turbulence; radial correlation length; long-wavelength density turbulence; hot tokamak plasmas; realistic experimental geometries; common-mode fluctuation; density fluctuations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Spectrometer system and detector tests for the TFTR alpha-CHERS experiment
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.Keyword: alpha-particle spectrometers|charge exchange|detectors|ion recombination|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma heating|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An optical spectroscopy diagnostic has been designed to observe emissions from the nonthermal alpha particle population that will be generated during the D-T operation phase on TFTR. The system will observe spectral line emission near 469 nm from the slowing-down alpha population interacting with the heating neutral beams through charge exchange. The required spectrometer throughput and resolution are obtained by modification of a simple commercial spectrometer system, while a series of measurements indicate that a cooled CCD array is usable as a high-efficiency detector with photon-noise-limited accuracy to roughly a part in 104
z:row.User2: alpha-charge exchange recombination spectroscopy; optical spectroscopy diagnostic; emissions; nonthermal alpha particle population; D-T operation phase; TFTR; slowing-down alpha population; heating neutral beams; spectrometer throughput; resolution; cooled CCD array; high-efficiency detector; photon-noise-limited accuracy; 469 nm

z:row.TitlePrimary: Remote operation of the TFTR BES experiment from an off-site location
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.Keyword: computer networks|fusion reactor ignition|fusion reactor operation|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma toroidal confinement|telecontrol
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The capability of controlling a diagnostic subsystem and interactively participating in the experimental program on Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR) from a remote site has been developed and demonstrated on the TFTR BES experiment. Interactive communications are established from multiscreen remote workstations at the University of Wisconsin to the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory VAX cluster via multiple terminal sessions across the InterNet national network. Full control of the diagnostic, access to all relevant machine parameters and wave forms, and operations run logs are all available with automatic updates between plasma shots. A real-time count-down shot clock with timer, machine event status, and shot number provides a real-time interface to the TFTR shot sequence. This means of remote participation in a central fusion experiment provides vital experience for extrapolation to implementation on an ignition device to test engineering concepts
z:row.User2: beam emission spectroscopy; off-site location; diagnostic subsystem; Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor; TFTR; multiscreen remote workstations; VAX cluster; multiple terminal sessions; InterNet national network; operations run logs; automatic updates; plasma shots; real-time count-down shot clock; machine event status; shot number; real-time interface; fusion experiment; ignition device; engineering concepts

z:row.TitlePrimary: A simple multifoil spectrometer for routine carbon and oxygen measurements
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.Keyword: pinch effect|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma toroidal confinement|X-ray spectrometers
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A simple multifoil Ross filter spectrometer for monitoring principal (i.e. n=2-1) soft X-ray lines of H- and He-like carbon and oxygen has been installed on the Madison symmetric torus reversed-field pinch. It consists of four silicon surface barrier diodes, each covered by a different multilayer foil filter but viewing a common plasma volume. Each filter is composed of a combination of thin film absorbers with strategically located absorption edges, giving a peak transmission of around 10% at a wavelength of interest (C v 40.30 Å, C VI 33.74 Å, O VII 21.70 Å, O VIII 18.90 Å) with good rejection of the others. A linear combination of these four lines is isolated by a given filter and a matrix inversion of the four simultaneous measurements produces the intensities of the individual lines. The time evolution of these lines shows evidence of radial shell structure and gives useful information of the dynamics of the electron temperature during sawtooth activity. This multifoil spectrometer provides a simple and inexpensive alternative to grazing incidence spectrometers as a monitor of C and O influx and radiated power in high temperature tokamaks, and may be especially applicable in a high neutron flux environment
z:row.User2: H-like ion; He-like ion; line intensities; multifoil spectrometer; Ross filter spectrometer; soft X-ray lines; Madison symmetric torus reversed-field pinch; surface barrier diodes; plasma volume; thin film absorbers; absorption edges; peak transmission; matrix inversion; time evolution; radial shell structure; electron temperature; sawtooth activity; high temperature tokamaks; high neutron flux environment; Cn+; On+

z:row.TitlePrimary: Density fluctuation measurements via beam emission spectroscopy
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.Keyword: fluctuations|plasma density|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma diagnostics|plasma turbulence
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin/Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Previous studies of plasma microturbulence have indicated that the fluctuation power sales with radial wave number, k⊥, like k⊥-2→k⊥-3.5 for k⊥>2 cm-1. This implies that low k fluctuations may dominate the spectrum. Beam emission spectroscopy (BES) has been developed to provide spatially localized measurements of density fluctuations in this low k region of the spectrum (k⊥-1). A 20-channel system has been installed on TFTR which images one of the heating neutral beams (via fiber optics) onto a set of photoconductive photodiode detectors. Fluctuations in the fluorescent Dα emission from the beam can be related to the local plasma density fluctuations via a model of the atomic excitation processes. The analysis of BES data utilizes many of the standard statistical analysis techniques such as power spectra, coherency and cross phase, and correlation analysis which are also used in the analysis of, for example, Langmuir probe data. In the case of BES however, these techniques require some special modifications to account for systematic effects such as photon statistics and fluctuations in the neutral beam density induced by the strong fluctuations near the plasma edge
z:row.User2: density fluctuation measurements; beam emission spectroscopy; plasma microturbulence; TFTR; photoconductive photodiode detectors; fluorescent Dα emission; plasma density fluctuations; atomic excitation; statistical analysis; power spectra; Langmuir probe; photon statistics

z:row.TitlePrimary: Low-noise photodiode detector for optical fluctuation diagnostics
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 15-19 March 1992
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Santa Fe, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The beam emission spectroscopy optical fluctuation diagnostic requires the highest possible quantum efficiency detector at 656 nm to minimize the photon statistical baseline limit to the detectable fluctuation level. A photoconductive photodiode detector with an extremely low-noise preamplifier and a reactive feedback circuit provides quantum efficiencies up to 70%-80% for a useful frequency range of at least 0-150 kHz with incident powers of ~10 nW. The diodes are chosen for negligible leakage current and hence do not require active cooling. These detectors have provided increase in the sensitivity to plasma fluctuation amplitude by a factor of ~14 over photomultipliers and a factor of 4 over large area avalanche photodiodes
z:row.User2: low-noise photodiode detector; plasma; optical fluctuation diagnostics; beam emission spectroscopy; photoconductive photodiode; reactive feedback circuit; quantum efficiencies; 656 nm; 10 nW; 0 to 150 kHz

z:row.TitlePrimary: Measurements of the radial structure and poloidal spectra of toroidal Alfven eigenmodes in the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor
z:row.Keyword: magnetohydrodynamic waves|plasma diagnostics|plasma instability|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma waves|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Toroidal Alfven eigenmodes (TAE) have been excited by tangential neutral beam injection in the Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor (TFTR) [Proceedings of the Thirteenth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 1990, Washington, D.C. (International Atomic Energy Agency, Vienna, 1990), vol.I, p.9]. Beam emission spectroscopy (BES) has been used to study the radial structure and the poloidal power spectra of these modes. Radial profiles show a global, standing wave structure with a node near r/a=0.6 and a maximum displacement of about 5-10 mm. The cross-phase profiles and the power spectra both imply that the mode is composed of a mixture of components with various poloidal and toroidal mode numbers, as expected for the TAE. Measurements of the poloidal mode spectrum via BES show good agreement with theoretical simulations performed by a nonvariational, kinetic magnetohydrodynamics stability code (NOVA-K [Cheng, Phys. Rep. 211, 1 (1992)]). In particular, the dominant harmonics in the poloidal spectrum obey the expected relation m+1/2≈q(r)n
z:row.User2: beam emission spectroscopy; global standing wave structure; poloidal mode numbers; toroidal Alfven eigenmodes; Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor; tangential neutral beam injection; TFTR; radial structure; poloidal power spectra; displacement; cross-phase profiles; toroidal mode numbers; harmonics

z:row.TitlePrimary: Fluctuation measurements in the plasma interior on TFTR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Physics 1992. Joint Conference of the 9th Kiev International Conference on Plasma Theory, 9th International Congress on Waves and Instabilities in Plasmas and 19th European Physical Society Conference on Controlled Fusion and Plasma Physics, 29 June-3 July 1992

z:row.Abstract: New beam emission spectroscopy and correlation reflectometry density fluctuation diagnostics on TFTR allow examination of the crucial long wavelength (k⊥ρiE decreases. Radial and poloidal correlation lengths from BES are comparable and are roughly 2-3 cm near the plasma edge and gradually drop to 1-2 cm in the region of r/a=0.5-0.7. Values decreases. z:row.TitlePrimary: Current drive experiments in the Phaedrus-T tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on RF Power in Plasmas, 19-21 Aug. 1991
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Charleston, SC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experiments in progress on the Phaedrus-T tokamak focus on effects associated with fast wave current drive at low harmonics of the cyclotron frequency, typically either 3 ΩCD or 1.5 ΩCH on axis. Areas of investigation include edge effects, directionality of wave launch, and comparison of wave absorption to numerical predictions. More general aspects of current drive, such as wave helicity effects which can be viewed as part of a complete picture of the nonlinear contributions to current drive, will be extensively studied. Early Thomson scattering data appears to indicate that RF power coupling to electrons is affected by antenna phasing. However, current drive has not yet been observed. Several innovations have also been implemented on the experiment, including insulating limiters on the Faraday shield to reduce RF-edge plasma interactions, an antenna design which reduces inductive coupling between the straps for operation at arbitrary phase, modelling of the coupled straps to allow predictive retuning on phase changes, and a two-channel transformer coupled transmitter
z:row.User2: Phaedrus-T tokamak; fast wave current drive; cyclotron frequency; edge effects; wave absorption; numerical predictions; wave helicity effects; Thomson scattering data; antenna phasing; two-channel transformer coupled transmitter

z:row.TitlePrimary: RF edge interactions and insulating limiters in Phaedrus-T
z:row.TitleSecondary: Ninth Topical Conference on RF Power in Plasmas, 19-21 Aug. 1991
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Charleston, SC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Inductively generated RF sheaths and self-bias effects at antenna Faraday screens are at least partly responsible for the impurity influx and edge modifications often seen in RF heating experiments. Analysis of JET results has shown that the effectiveness of solutions utilized in that experiment to reduce RF impurity influxes can be explained in terms of RF sheath effects. On both JET and TFTR magnetic field-aligned Faraday shield elements, low-Z coatings, and 180° phasing of adjacent antenna straps have been effective at reducing impurities. However, alignment of Faraday shield elements is difficult, low-Z coatings do not remove the underlying causes of sputtering, and 180° phasing reduces loading resistance and is incompatible with certain RF goals, such as fast wave current drive. Here the authors show that RF generated impurity influxes in the Phaedrus-T tokamak are due to self-bias effects in the edge plasma generated by RF sheaths at the Faraday shield, and that these effects can be largely eliminated for any antenna phasing by the use of insulating limiters on the Faraday shield
z:row.User2: RF edge interactions; insulating limiters; Phaedrus-T; RF sheaths; self-bias effects; antenna Faraday screens; impurity influx; edge modifications; RF heating; low-Z coatings; sputtering; fast wave current drive; tokamak; edge plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Line shapes in charge exchange recombination spectroscopy
z:row.TitleSecondary: 10th International Conference on Spectral Line Shapes, 25-29 June 1990
z:row.Keyword: atomic spectral line breadth|plasma collision processes|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma temperature|plasma-beam interactions|Stark effect|Zeeman effect
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Austin, TX, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Production and excitation of hydrogenic light ions in hot plasmas via charge exchange recombination interactions has become the method of choice for the measurements of plasma ion temperatures and rotation velocities. Several atomic physics and environmental effects can conspire to cause perturbations of the measured line profile, and hence reduce the reliability of these measurements. Unresolved atomic fine structure is sometimes nonnegligible and can cause both an artificial asymmetry and broadening of the line. At high magnetic fields, both Zeeman and motional Stark line broadening can make reliable measurements problematic. At the high thermal energies found in contemporary fusion plasmas, the cross section for charge exchange between a plasma ion and a monoenergetic beam neutral can change appreciably across the ion velocity distribution and hence across the line profile. With the proper beam-sightline orientation, this can lead to large and measurable changes in the apparent ion temperatures and rotation velocities
z:row.User2: plasma rotation velocities; line shapes; Zeeman line broadening; hot plasmas; charge exchange recombination interactions; plasma ion temperatures; environmental effects; perturbations; line profile; atomic fine structure; artificial asymmetry; broadening; motional Stark line broadening; fusion plasmas; cross section; monoenergetic beam neutral; beam-sightline orientation; ion temperatures; H like ions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma fluctuation measurements in Tokamaks using beam-plasma interactions
z:row.TitleSecondary: 8th Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 6-10 May 1990
z:row.Keyword: fluorescence|particle beam diagnostics|plasma density|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma heating|plasma toroidal confinement|plasma turbulence|plasma-beam interactions|Tokamak devices
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Hyannis, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, MI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. High-frequency observations of light emitted from the interactions between plasma ions and injected neutral beam atoms allow the measurement of moderate-wavelength fluctuations in plasma and impurity ion densities. To detect turbulence in the local plasma ion density, the collisionally excited fluorescence from a neutral beam is measured either separately at several spatial points or with a multichannel imaging detector. Similarly, the role of impurity ion density fluctuations is measured using charge exchange recombination excited transitions emitted by the ion species of interest. This technique can access the relatively unexplored region of long-wavelength plasma turbulence with k⊥ρi≪1, and hence complements measurements from scattering experiments. Optimization of neutral beam geometry and optical sightlines can result in very good localization and resolution (Δx⩽1 cm) in the hot plasma core region. The detectable fluctuation level is determined by photon statistics, atomic excitation processes, and beam stability, but can be as low as 0.2% in a 100 kHz bandwidth over the 0-1 MHz frequency range. The choices of beam species (e.g., H0, He0, etc.), observed transition (e.g., Hα, Lα, He I singlet or triplet transitions, C VI Δn=1, etc.) are dictated by experiment-specific factors such as optical access, flexibility of beam operation, plasma conditions, and detailed experimental goals. Initial tests on the PBX-M Tokamak using the Hα emissions from a heating neutral beam show low-frequency turbulence in the edge plasma region
z:row.User2: plasma fluctuation measurements; plasma diagnostics; Tokamaks; beam-plasma interactions; injected neutral beam atoms; moderate-wavelength fluctuations; impurity ion densities; local plasma ion density; collisionally excited fluorescence; charge exchange recombination excited transitions; long-wavelength plasma turbulence; detectable fluctuation level; photon statistics; atomic excitation processes; beam stability; low-frequency turbulence; edge plasma region; 100 kHz; 0 to 1 MHz

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam emission spectroscopy diagnostic for the study of turbulence in Phaedrus-T tokamak plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: 8th Topical Conference on High Temperature Plasma Diagnostics, 6-10 May 1990
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor instrumentation|plasma density|plasma diagnostics|plasma turbulence|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Hyannis, MA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A flexible beam emission spectroscopy diagnostic system is being installed on the Phaedrus-T tokamak. It consists of a low-power diagnostic neutral beam (H0 or He0) coupled with visible and vacuum UV collection optics to study low-amplitude, high-frequency fluctuations in local plasma density in ohmically and RF-heated plasmas. Neutral beam geometry and optical sightlines are chosen to optimize localization and radial resolution () coupled with visible and vacuum UV collection optics to study low-amplitude, high-frequency fluctuations in local plasma density in ohmically and RF-heated plasmas. Neutral beam geometry and optical sightlines are chosen to optimize localization and radial resolution (α, Lα, He singlet or triplet lines, etc.) to be compared and optimized for a given experimental condition
z:row.User2: plasma turbulence; vacuum UV spectrum; visible spectrum; neutral beam geometry; singlet lines; ohmically heated plasma; Phaedrus-T tokamak plasmas; flexible beam emission spectroscopy diagnostic system; low-power diagnostic neutral beam; visible and vacuum UV collection optics; high-frequency fluctuations; local plasma density; RF-heated plasmas; radial resolution; atomic transitions; triplet lines; He neutral beam; H neutral beam

z:row.Keyword: ion density|plasma density|plasma diagnostic techniques|plasma turbulence|plasma-beam interactions|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High-frequency observations of light emitted from the interactions between plasma ions and injected neutral beam atoms allow the measurement of moderate-wavelength fluctuations in plasma and impurity ion densities. To detect turbulence in the local plasma ion density, the collisionally excited fluorescence from a neutral beam is measured either separately at several spatial points or with a multichannel imaging detector. z:row.TitlePrimary: Atomic processes and spectroscopic techniques applied to fusion plasma diagnostics
z:row.TitleSecondary: 7th American Physical Society Topical Conference on Atomic Processes in Plasmas, 2-5 Oct. 1989
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Gaithersburg, MD, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A wide variety of spectroscopic techniques exploiting several different atomic processes are used to study the properties of high temperature magnetically confined plasmas. The methods of choice in present experiments use either charge exchange recombination reactions between plasma ions and light neutral atoms injected via high energy neutral beams or fluorescence of beam-injected neutrals excited via collisions with the plasma constituent species. While these techniques allow accurate studies of plasma equilibria, transport properties, and possibly microturbulence in contemporary experiments, the low probability of penetration of neutral beams into dense hot plasmas suggests that extrapolation of these techniques to future fusion ignition experiments may be difficult, and alternative diagnostic techniques based on more classical emission line spectroscopy must also be explored
z:row.User2: spectroscopic techniques; fusion plasma diagnostics; atomic processes; high temperature magnetically confined plasmas; charge exchange recombination reactions; fluorescence; plasma equilibria; transport properties; microturbulence

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comparison of atomic quasi-Landau spectrum with semiclassical strong-field-mixing models
z:row.Keyword: atomic fine structure|atomic resonant states|barium|strontium|WKB calculations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Phys. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors compare the spectrum of the regularly spaced photoabsorption resonances which appear in the vicinity of the ionization threshold for atoms in a strong magnetic field with predictions of semiclassical strong-mixing models. Quasi-Landau resonance positions are shown to agree well with a two-dimensional WKB semiclassical hydrogenic model which depicts the resonances as bound states of the electron in the combined Coulomb and magnetic fields and which reduces to the Rydberg levels at low excitation. Simpler treatments based on a modified Bohr atomic model are also discussed. The data include observations in the M=0 even-parity channels of Ba I and Sr I with B=25-40 kG and the M=-1 odd-parity channel of Ba I at B=47 kG. A scaling procedure is used to allow field-independent comparison among the various spectra and models. Although fairly successful in predicting energy positions, none of the models attempts to explain the complex resonance profiles or superposed fine structure, thus indicating the need for a comprehensive quantum-mechanical theory of the diamagnetic strong-mixing regime. The appearance of the quasi-Landau resonances in M=0 even-parity spectra is consistent with the requirement that the states have even parity with respect to reflection along the direction of the magnetic field in order for the resonances to occur
z:row.User2: photoabsorption resonances; ionization threshold; strong magnetic field; bound states; magnetic fields; Rydberg levels; Bohr atomic model; Ba I; Sr I; scaling procedure; resonance profiles; fine structure; strong mixing model; quasiLandau spectrum; odd parity channel; quasiLandau resonance; quantum mechanical theory; diamagnetic strong mixing regime; WKB model; Coulomb field

z:row.TitlePrimary: Atomic diamagnetism: quasi-Landau spectrum near the ionisation threshold
z:row.Keyword: atomic resonant states|barium|diamagnetism|ionisation of atoms|magneto-optical effects|photoionisation|strontium|two-photon spectra
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Phys. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Observations are reported of quasi-Landau resonances in the even-parity spectra of Ba and Sr near their first ionisation thresholds using two-photon ionisation spectroscopy. The positions and B-dependence of the resonances are found to agree with semiclassical calculations. The resonance profiles of Ba differ greatly from those of Sr
z:row.User2: ionisation threshold; Ba; Sr; B-dependence; resonance profiles; quasiLandau spectrum; even parity channels; magnetic field strength; atomic diamagnetism; two photon ionisation; two photon laser spectra

z:row.TitlePrimary: All-reflection Michelson interferometer: analysis and test for far IR Fourier spectroscopy
z:row.Keyword: diffraction gratings|Fourier transform spectroscopy|interference spectrometers|optical elements|spectrometer components and accessories
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Phys., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The beam splitter of the all-reflection Michelson interferometer consists of a combination of three parallel diffraction gratings. This paper extends the analysis of the instrument to include the effects of lateral errors in the grating adjustment (i.e., displacements parallel to the grating faces and perpendicular to the grooves). Such errors are shown to introduce a phase shift independent of wavenumber and proportional to grating order number. Tests of an instrument designed for Fourier transform spectroscopy in the 500-1000-μm spectral range are reported and shown to be in agreement with the analysis. For wavenumbers which pass through the instrument in 2 or more orders, cross-order interference effects are expected to occur which cause rapid variations in the efficiency vs wavenumber curve. This possibility should be eliminated in the design of a practical instrument. The resolution of the test instrument (1.6 cm-1) was insufficient to reveal this effect
z:row.User2: far IR Fourier spectroscopy; beam splitter; three parallel diffraction gratings; lateral errors; grating adjustment; phase shift; all reflection Michelson interferometer; 500 to 1000 microns spectral range; cross order interference effects

z:row.TitlePrimary: Atomic diamagnetism and diamagnetically induced configuration mixing in laser-excited barium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Phys. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The behaviour of highly excited even-parity states of neutral barium in magnetic fields between 20 and 40 kiloGauss have been studied by the technique of absorption spectroscopy out of a laser populated lower level. The energy shifts of the 6s6p1P10-6s ns 1S0 Rydberg series were observed. In regions where the interactions with states of the 5d7d configuration are strong the shift is perturbed to below the hydrogenic value. Diamagnetically induced mixing enhances the intensity of higher members of the 1S0 series
z:row.User2: diamagnetically induced configuration mixing; absorption spectroscopy; laser populated lower level; Rydberg series; atomic diamagnetism; laser excited; Ba; 20 to 40 kG; diamagnetic Zeeman effect; highly excited even parity states; diamagnetically induced mixing

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of neoclassical diffusion effects on plasma losses produced by magnetic field asymmetries
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The previous diffusion model of plasma loss was extended to low collision frequency by using the formalism of neoclassical diffusion theory. New experimental results obtained on a single ring device were found to be in semiquantitative agreement with this model
z:row.User2: neoclassical diffusion effects; plasma losses; magnetic field asymmetries; diffusion model; low collision frequency; single ring device
